original_data.question: A previously healthy 67-year-old man comes to the physician for routine health maintenance evaluation. He works at a community center and volunteers at a local homeless shelter. A tuberculin skin test shows an induration of 14 mm. An x-ray of the chest is normal. Treatment with an antimycobacterial drug is initiated. Two months later, he has numbness and burning over both feet and an unsteady gait. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to light touch extending from the soles of the feet to the mid-shin bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patientâ€™s current symptoms?

options.D: Impaired breakdown of glucose to ATP

model_response:
The patient has developed a peripheral neuropathy as a result of isoniazid-induced pyridoxine deficiency. Isoniazid inhibits the synthesis of S-adenosylmethionine, which is necessary for the formation of pyridoxal phosphate, an essential cofactor in the metabolism of tryptophan and synthesis of niacin. In individuals with marginal nutritional status, isoniazid may lead to a deficiency of pyridoxine and the development of a peripheral neuropathy due to the accumulation of 5-hydroxytryptophan and increased activity of the enzyme 5-hydroxytryptophan dehydrogenase. The neuropathy is usually reversible with pyridoxine supplementation. The other choices are not related to isoniazid or pyridoxine deficiency.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Having no significant health-related issues.
Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Having a black or dark core or plug.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
An unvarying or habitual method or procedure.
The state of the organism when it functions optimally without evidence of disease.
Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.

Description:A location that plays the role of delivering services which may include providing front-line services to the population of a defined geographic area such as: healthcare services and social services, preventive or curative, rehabilitation or reintegration.
Persons who donate their services.
Housing created or provided for ILL-HOUSED PERSONS.

One of several skin tests to determine past or present tuberculosis infection. A purified protein derivative of the tubercle bacilli, called tuberculin, is introduced into the skin by scratch, puncture, or interdermal injection.
The quality of being hard, the process of hardening, or an abnormally hard spot or place, particularly of the skin.
Used with organs, regions, and diseases for x-ray examinations.
The upper part of the trunk between the NECK and the ABDOMEN. It contains the chief organs of the circulatory and respiratory systems. (From Stedman, 25th ed)

Used with diseases for therapeutic interventions except drug therapy, diet therapy, radiotherapy, and surgery, for which specific subheadings exist. The concept is also used for articles and books dealing with multiple therapies.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Absent or reduced sensitivity to cutaneous stimulation.
A sensation of stinging or heat, not necessarily accompanied by redness or physical signs of irritation.
The distal extremity of the leg in vertebrates, consisting of the tarsus (ANKLE); METATARSUS; phalanges; and the soft tissues surrounding these bones.
A shaky or wobbly manner of walking.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A subjective response indicating that something is or has decreased.

The process in which specialized SENSORY RECEPTOR CELLS transduce peripheral stimuli (physical or chemical) into NERVE IMPULSES which are then transmitted to the various sensory centers in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM.
The undersurface of the foot.
The distal extremity of the leg in vertebrates, consisting of the tarsus (ANKLE); METATARSUS; phalanges; and the soft tissues surrounding these bones.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
